front.title: URI Scheme for Session Traversal Utilities for NAT (STUN) Protocol

abstract.t: This document is the specification of the syntax and semantics of the Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) scheme for the Session Traversal Utilities for NAT (STUN) protocol.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: This document specifies the syntax and semantics of the Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) scheme for the Session Traversal Utilities for NAT (STUN) protocol.

STUN is a protocol that serves as a tool for other protocols in dealing with Network Address Translator (NAT) travesal. It can be used by an endpoint to determine the IP address and port allocated to it by a NAT, to perform connectivity checks between two endpoints, and used as a keep=alive protocol to maintain NAT bindings. RFC 5389 defines the specifics of the STUN protocol.

The 'stun/stuns' URI scheme is used to designate a standalone STUN server or any Internet host performing the operations of a STUN server in the context of STUN usages (section 14 RFC 5389 ). Such an URI scheme allows a uniform way to describe, configure and pass around the information identifyng a STUN server. This would prevent the short-comings inherent with encoding similar information in non-uniform syntaxes such as the ones proposed in WEBRTC Standards , for example.
The 'stun/stuns' URI follows the common Internet scheme syntax as defined in RFC 3986 ..

section.title: Terminology
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119 .

section.title: URI Scheme Syntax
section.t: The 'stun/stuns' URI takes the following form (the syntax below is non-normative):

stun:<userinfo>@<host>:<port>
stuns:<userinfo>@<host>:<port>
where <userinfo> with the "@" (at) sign character, as well as the <port> part and the preceding ":" (colon) character, is OPTIONAL
The normative syntax of the 'stun' URI is defined as shown in the following Augmented Backusâ€“Naur Form (ABNF) [RFC5234] rule:

section.title: URI Scheme Semantics
section.t: The STUN protocol supports sending messages over UDP, TCP or TLS-over-TCP. The 'stuns' URI scheme SHALL be used when STUN is run over TLS-over-TCP and the 'stun' scheme SHALL be used otherwise. The <host> part of the 'stun' URI, which is REQUIRED, denotes the STUN server host. The <userinfo> part, which is OPTIONAL, identifies the credential in the form of a username and password as required by the optional authentication and message integrity procedures described in section 10 of RFC 5389 . Such a credential may used by STUN end-points to authenticate and protect integrity of STUN messages, say, to perform connectivity checks.The interactions involving STUN clients and standalone STUN Servers SHALL NOT utlilize any credential mechanisms as described in the section 13 of RFC 5389 . The <port> part,if present,denotes the port on which the STUN server is awaiting connection requests. For a standlone STUN server the port SHALL default to 3478 for both UDP and TCP. The default port for TLS shall be 5349.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This document instructs IANA to register the 'stun' URI in the "Permanent URI Schemes" sub-registry in the "Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) Schemes" IANA registry . This registration follows the URI Scheme Registration Template detailed in Section 5.4 of RFC 4395 .

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The URI Scheme defined by this document for the Session Traversal Utilities for NAT (STUN) protocol does not introduce any security considerations beyond those detailed in Section 16 of RFC 5389 .
